description: In this series, Vonne and Justin explore the intricate world of Object-Oriented Programming(OOP), particularly in the context of the Python programming language. Starting with the basics of OOP, Justin demonstrates the creation of classes and associated objects from those classes. Moreover, Justin demonstrates the use of Inheritance of classes to reduce code repetitiveness in an effort to adhere to the Don't Repeat Yourself (DRY) principle. Lastly, Justin builds a simple OOP centric text-based adventure. If you are ready to get into Object-Oriented Python, then join us!

8

And in this episode we're

9

what exactly is object
oriented programing?

10
00:00:28.630 --> 00:00:31.560
And here to help us is Mr.
Justin Dennis and hello Justin.

13

I am glad that you're here to help us

14
00:00:37.570 --> 00:00:39.390

15
00:00:39.390 --> 00:00:41.960
>> Well Vonne I am excited

16
00:00:41.960 --> 00:00:44.350
This is a topic that we

17
00:00:44.350 --> 00:00:45.550

18
00:00:45.550 --> 00:00:47.870
What is object oriented programing?

19
00:00:47.870 --> 00:00:51.723
And sometimes I feel
like I don't know myself.

20
00:00:51.723 --> 00:00:55.328
But in fact we're gonna hit on what

21
00:00:55.328 --> 00:01:00.460
Particularly it's a set of vocabulary,

22
00:01:00.460 --> 00:01:03.485
How do I approach these
programming problems?

23
00:01:03.485 --> 00:01:07.970
And we won't have a lot of programming,
per se, in this episode.

24
00:01:07.970 --> 00:01:09.850

25
00:01:09.850 --> 00:01:11.370
How do I design these systems?

26

How do I build these systems?

27
00:01:12.640 --> 00:01:18.730
How do I follow these sets of
ideas to help us abstract a way to

28
00:01:18.730 --> 00:01:23.870
create these systems of software?

29

Particularly in object oriented

30
00:01:27.910 --> 00:01:29.872
Now this may vary depending

31
00:01:29.872 --> 00:01:32.279
Some people add a fifth one,

32
00:01:32.279 --> 00:01:37.187

33
00:01:37.187 --> 00:01:40.190

34
00:01:40.190 --> 00:01:42.300
So those are our four principles of

35
00:01:43.320 --> 00:01:47.340
object oriented programming that we
have to figure out, what do they mean?

36
00:01:47.340 --> 00:01:48.290
What's going on?

00:01:48.290 --> 00:01:50.680
>> All right, so those sound

00:01:50.680 --> 00:01:52.250
So we're gonna go through

39
00:01:52.250 --> 00:01:54.070
So let's start with encapsulation.

40
00:01:54.070 --> 00:01:55.150
What are we talking about here?

41
00:01:55.150 --> 00:02:01.761
>> So encapsulation, that's, [SOUND] man,

00:02:07.310 --> 00:02:08.550

45
00:02:08.550 --> 00:02:11.120

00:02:11.120 --> 00:02:16.700
so let's look at this nice little

47
00:02:16.700 --> 00:02:18.708

48
00:02:18.708 --> 00:02:20.222
>> That looks like an engine.

49
00:02:20.222 --> 00:02:21.347
>> That is an engine.

50
00:02:21.347 --> 00:02:24.906
And encapsulation means that all
the inner workings, all of the data,

51
00:02:24.906 --> 00:02:27.480
all of the states kind of bundle together,
right?

52
00:02:27.480 --> 00:02:29.280
An engine can be running or not running.

53
00:02:29.280 --> 00:02:32.640
And we don't think about it when we
walk out to our cars in the morning.

54
00:02:32.640 --> 00:02:35.108
Turn it on, an engine fires.

55
00:02:35.108 --> 00:02:36.560
But there are all these things,

56
00:02:36.560 --> 00:02:41.650
all these changes that have occurred and
that is effectively encapsulation.

57
00:02:41.650 --> 00:02:44.770
I don't know how the engine comes on.

58
00:02:44.770 --> 00:02:47.500
I just know that it comes
on when I turn the key.

59
00:02:47.500 --> 00:02:49.600
So that state, those methods,

60
00:02:49.600 --> 00:02:53.600
the implementation of how that
works is hidden away from me.

61
00:02:53.600 --> 00:02:58.590
And when I turn on the engine,
I actually end up, this is a hard one,

62
00:02:58.590 --> 00:03:01.740
this is a nice little wheel
rolling down the road.

63
00:03:01.740 --> 00:03:04.000
My engine turns on, and my car goes.

64
00:03:04.000 --> 00:03:07.700
So, I don't know how that works,
but it actually works.

65
00:03:07.700 --> 00:03:09.830
So encapsulation is
the hiding of that state

66
00:03:11.660 --> 00:03:15.600
to where we don't have to worry
about how it works, it just works.

67
00:03:15.600 --> 00:03:19.560
Now along with that is the level
of Abstraction, right.

68
00:03:19.560 --> 00:03:21.230
So these are tied closely together.

69
00:03:22.270 --> 00:03:26.310
And what Abstraction is, in a technical
sense, is a consistent set of properties

70
00:03:27.330 --> 00:03:31.990
and behavior that are bundled
together inside of an object.

71
00:03:31.990 --> 00:03:34.300
Now let's take this object for

72
00:03:34.300 --> 00:03:40.430

73
00:03:40.430 --> 00:03:45.340

00:03:45.340 --> 00:03:48.667
>> So Vonne has made a very
accurate description.

75
00:03:48.667 --> 00:03:52.470
It's a red car,
it's got a couple of wheels, some doors.

76
00:03:52.470 --> 00:03:56.212
And that's important because
there's a lot more to this car.

77
00:03:56.212 --> 00:03:59.250
If we really wanted to get into
the nitty gritty details, right.

78
00:03:59.250 --> 00:04:02.780
If I wanted to dig inside, well is it
a five speed or is it an automatic?

79
00:04:02.780 --> 00:04:04.070
Is it a six speed?

80
00:04:04.070 --> 00:04:08.010
Does it have all-wheel drive,
two-wheel drive, front-wheel drive?

81
00:04:08.010 --> 00:04:09.849
Does it have a full trunk space?

82
00:04:09.849 --> 00:04:11.270
Is the engine in the front or the rear?

83
00:04:11.270 --> 00:04:13.762
Is it a V8, a four cylinder?

84
00:04:13.762 --> 00:04:15.805
There are a lot of questions
that can be asked.

85
00:04:15.805 --> 00:04:17.899
And what I find with abstraction,

86
00:04:17.899 --> 00:04:20.940
the whole purpose of
abstraction is to pull away.

87
00:04:20.940 --> 00:04:25.600
And look at only what you care about
in the context, the set of interfaces.

88
00:04:25.600 --> 00:04:27.400
What do I mean by interfaces?

89
00:04:27.400 --> 00:04:28.720
How do you interact with it?

90
00:04:28.720 --> 00:04:30.200
How do I interact with a car?

91
00:04:30.200 --> 00:04:32.590
Well, I get in,
I put my key in the ignition,

92
00:04:32.590 --> 00:04:35.570
I turn it on and I drive it to work.

93
00:04:35.570 --> 00:04:38.020
And what's important in that context?

94
00:04:38.020 --> 00:04:39.790
The ability to get in the car,
so the doors.

95
00:04:40.830 --> 00:04:45.380
The ability to turn it on, so the key and
the fuel tank and the engine.

96
00:04:45.380 --> 00:04:46.461
Those work.

97
00:04:46.461 --> 00:04:48.653
But those are hidden away from me.

98
00:04:48.653 --> 00:04:50.982
But at that moment I
don't care what it is.

99
00:04:50.982 --> 00:04:53.410
And that's what is important
about abstraction.

100
00:04:53.410 --> 00:04:58.732
So if we look at it, if I'm
designing a car, some car simulator.

101
00:04:58.732 --> 00:05:03.569
Maybe the only pieces of information that
I need about the car in that context

102
00:05:03.569 --> 00:05:06.130
are the number of wheels.

103
00:05:06.130 --> 00:05:08.270
What color is it?

104
00:05:08.270 --> 00:05:09.940
How many doors does it have?

105
00:05:09.940 --> 00:05:14.800
And if I'm building, let's say, either
a simulator or maybe an inventory system.

106
00:05:14.800 --> 00:05:17.050
Maybe that's all I need
to know about the car.

107
00:05:17.050 --> 00:05:20.603
I don't need to know what is its
top speed in those contexts.

108
00:05:20.603 --> 00:05:21.980
For the simulator, I might.

109
00:05:21.980 --> 00:05:25.420
But for the inventory system,
I would not, right.

110
00:05:25.420 --> 00:05:27.030
So that's for a car.

111
00:05:27.030 --> 00:05:28.710
Let's look at a little different example.

112
00:05:30.510 --> 00:05:35.650
So Vonne, do you have a lock
to some portion of your house,

113
00:05:35.650 --> 00:05:38.105
or a keepsake box, or anything like that?

114
00:05:38.105 --> 00:05:39.570
>> Mm-hm.

115
00:05:39.570 --> 00:05:42.370
>> Do you have a key to that?

116
00:05:42.370 --> 00:05:45.580
>> Yes, I have a key on my key ring
that I use and I put it in the lock and

117
00:05:45.580 --> 00:05:47.130
I turn it and I go in my house.

118
00:05:47.130 --> 00:05:50.310
>> Do you know how that lock actually
works, how your key opens the lock?

119
00:05:50.310 --> 00:05:50.890
>> No.

120
00:05:50.890 --> 00:05:52.070
>> Yeah, yeah.

121
00:05:52.070 --> 00:05:55.640
Most people don't know,
how does a lock work, right?

122
00:05:55.640 --> 00:05:57.660
Is it important in the context?

123
00:05:57.660 --> 00:05:58.850
No, I know I have a key,

124
00:05:58.850 --> 00:06:03.710
I know that I put the key in the slot and
I turn the key, and it comes unlocked.

125
00:06:03.710 --> 00:06:06.152
So, that's the whole
purpose of abstraction,

126
00:06:06.152 --> 00:06:08.661
that it's tightly coupled
with encapsulation.

127
00:06:08.661 --> 00:06:11.440
Because j ust like the car,
it's on or off.

128
00:06:11.440 --> 00:06:15.010
Or, just like the lock,
it's locked or unlocked, right?

129
00:06:15.010 --> 00:06:20.167
So we have that data hidden from us,
and how that's manipulated.

130
00:06:20.167 --> 00:06:23.237
But for abstraction we only care
about certain interfaces or

131
00:06:23.237 --> 00:06:25.110
properties that we care about.

132
00:06:25.110 --> 00:06:29.760
So those are tightly coupled but

00:06:32.408 --> 00:06:35.480

135
00:06:35.480 --> 00:06:37.000
We don't need to know

136
00:06:37.000 --> 00:06:40.790
We just turn the button on and

137
00:06:40.790 --> 00:06:45.154
And abstraction is where we're just
picking out the pieces that we need when

138
00:06:45.154 --> 00:06:48.508

the context of what we're doing.

139
00:06:48.508 --> 00:06:54.304
>> Right, and even then, we try to
talk about this to convey the idea.

00:06:54.304 --> 00:06:56.164
It's still very heady, right,
